did.unittitle: French Literature mss.
did.abstract: Consists of individual items acquired separately either as a gift or purchased from a variety of sources, relating to or by French literary figures. Additions continue to be made.
did.physloc: Lilly - Stacks; Lilly - Folio; Lilly - Vault 2 (Madame Bovary)

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.
Many collections are housed offsite; retrieval requires advance notice. Please make an appointment a minimum of one week in advance of your visit.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Received from various sources at various times. Accession information is given with the item entry. The most recent additions made in 2004.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: Photography and digitization may be restricted for some collections. Copyright restrictions may apply. Before publishing, researchers are responsible for securing permission from all applicable rights holders, then filling out the Permission to Publish form.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], French Literature mss., Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Consists of a collection of items received singly or in small groups from various sources at various times, which were not kept together as a distinct collection.

Note on Indexing Term - "Art": Of particular interest are 1917 L'Homme et Son Desir: poeme plastique by Paul Claudel with a collage by Audrey Parr; two drawings by Jean Cocteau from 1920 and 1929 and two drawings in blue pencil by Genevieve Asse.
For digitized content, see Digital Collections.

arrangement.head: Arrangement/Organization
arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically. Undated items are arranged alphabetically at the end of the series.

did.unittitle: French Literature mss.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Arranged chronologically at the item level, undated items are further arranged alphabetically

did.unittitle: Eighteenth-century feminist manuscript. Omelettes ou l'origine des Nouvelles Amazones. Ouvrage peu analogue à son titre, mais qui dit plus qu'il n'annonce. Divisé en chants puisque c'est un Poème. Par l'Auteur qui se soucie fort peu qu'on le connoisse. L'an de Grace et de disgrace 1773.; imprimé nulle part, puisqu'il ne mérite pas de l'être. Première et Dernière Édition. Prix: la peine de le lire. A most amusing mock-heroic verse satire on contemporary sexual mores. The saga recounts the tragic decline of amorous arts being foiled by the Goddess Discord by means of a treacherous omelette; and the final revenge of women in the formation of a new society of Amazons. Written out in a fine, flowing script with a hand-painted vignette on the title-page showing two men eating an omelette. This title is not listed in Gay-Lemonnyer and is probably unpublished.
did.physdesc: Octavo. 86pp. Bound in full contemporary calf with triple gilt rule. Spine gilt in six compartments. 19cm.

did.unittitle: Baudelaire, Charles Pierre, 1821-1867, poet. Fantòmes parisiens. A.D.

dao.xlink:title: 1859 June. Baudelaire, Charles Pierre, 1821-1867, poet. Fantòmes parisiens. A.D.

daodesc.p: 1859 June. Baudelaire, Charles Pierre, 1821-1867, poet. Fantòmes parisiens. A.D.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Author's signature has been clipped from another manuscript and pasted to the verso of the first leaf, signed "Tout à vous Ch. Baudelaire."
From the adjunct second leaf ¼ of the lower part has been cut off.
Written on the verso of the second leaf is a portion of a letter to an unnamed correspondent who has been idenitifed as Jean Morel, directeur of la Revue francaise.

Both poem and letter are undated but published under the assigned date of June, 1859, in Oeuvres Completes de Charles Baudelaire par M. Jacques Crepet (Paris, Editions Louis Conard) 1947, vol. 13, pages 321-324 (PQ2191 .A1 1923).
Poem first published in La Revue Contemporaine, September 15, 1859.
Significant variations from version published as "Les Sept Viellards" in the second edition of Les Fleurs du Mal in 1861 (Lilly PQ2191 .F6 1861).
Formerly in the library of Victor Meric.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchase. 1976

scopecontent.p: The seven leaves are hinged together to unfold to a length of 196 cm.
Enclosed in blue boards with white and gold lining.
Collage of figures in blue and white, in black and gold on blue by Mrs. Audrey (Bapst) Parr. Music by Darius Milhaud.
Yale University Library holds number 45 of the 53 manuscript copies of this work: Yale University Gazette, July 1975, page 60.
